title: New £1 could cost us £1.1bn in loose change | Daily Mail Online
text: Share It is thought around one in 30 £1 coins are fake. But a study found 87 per cent of people were unaware of the deadline, and that most people have around £15 in £1 coins in their home. For young people aged 18-14, this rises to £25. The new 12-sides £1 coin enters circulation in March. The Royal Mint has dubbed it the ‘most secure coin in the world’, and has been producing 2,000 of the new coins every minute. Old coins are valid tender until October, but can be returned or exchanged before that date The design features the flowers of the four home nations growing out of a crown, with the other side bearing the Queen’s head. Old coins are valid tender until October, but can be returned or exchanged before that date. They will then be melted down and used to make more of the new coin. New coins will feature special security measures including a hologram to make them harder to counterfeit. A '1' image will change into a '£' symbol depending on the angle it is viewed from. Other security measures include tiny lettering on both sides and milled edges. The new coin It is thinner and lighter than its predecessor, but it is larger in diameter. Mark Barnett, president of MasterCard UK and Ireland, told the Daily Telegraph: ‘We were shocked to discover just how few people are aware of when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation.’ Share or comment on this article Most watched News videos
